segment.source: Migrate EFS Files and Certificates (Windows 10)
segment.target: Migrate EFS Files and Certificates (Windows 10)

segment.source: Migrate EFS Files and Certificates
segment.target: Migrate EFS Files and Certificates

segment.source: Migrate EFS Files and Certificates
segment.target: Migrate EFS Files and Certificates

segment.source: This topic describes how to migrate Encrypting File System (EFS) certificates.
segment.target: This topic describes how to migrate Encrypting File System (EFS) certificates.

segment.source: For more information about the /efs For options, see ScanState Syntax.
segment.target: For more information about the /efs For options, see ScanState Syntax.

segment.source: To Migrate EFS Files and Certificates
segment.target: To Migrate EFS Files and Certificates

segment.source: Encrypting File System (EFS) certificates will be migrated automatically.
segment.target: Encrypting File System (EFS) certificates will be migrated automatically.

segment.source: However, by default, the User State Migration Tool (USMT) 10.0 fails if an encrypted file is found (unless you specify an /efs option).
segment.target: However, by default, the User State Migration Tool (USMT) 10.0 fails if an encrypted file is found (unless you specify an /efs option).

segment.source: Therefore, you must specify /efs:abort | skip | decryptcopy | copyraw | hardlink with the ScanState command to migrate the encrypted files.
segment.target: Therefore, you must specify /efs:abort | skip | decryptcopy | copyraw | hardlink with the ScanState command to migrate the encrypted files.

segment.source: Then, when you run the LoadState command on the destination computer, the encrypted file and the EFS certificate will be automatically migrated.
segment.target: Then, when you run the LoadState command on the destination computer, the encrypted file and the EFS certificate will be automatically migrated.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: The /efs options are not used with the LoadState command.
segment.target: The /efs options are not used with the LoadState command.

segment.source: Before using the ScanState tool for a migration that includes encrypted files and EFS certificates, you must ensure that all files in an encrypted folder are encrypted as well or remove the encryption attribute from folders that contain unencrypted files.
segment.target: Before using the ScanState tool for a migration that includes encrypted files and EFS certificates, you must ensure that all files in an encrypted folder are encrypted as well or remove the encryption attribute from folders that contain unencrypted files.

segment.source: If the encryption attribute has been removed from a file but not from the parent folder, the file will be encrypted during the migration using the credentials of the account used to run the LoadState tool.
segment.target: If the encryption attribute has been removed from a file but not from the parent folder, the file will be encrypted during the migration using the credentials of the account used to run the LoadState tool.

segment.source: You can run the Cipher tool at a Windows command prompt to review and change encryption settings on files and folders.
segment.target: You can run the Cipher tool at a Windows command prompt to review and change encryption settings on files and folders.

segment.source: For example, to remove encryption from a folder, at a command prompt type:
segment.target: For example, to remove encryption from a folder, at a command prompt type:

segment.source: Where Path is the full path of the topmost parent directory where the encryption attribute is set.
segment.target: Where Path is the full path of the topmost parent directory where the encryption attribute is set.
